--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Chris Dollin <chris.dollin@...> wrote:
> Read=
 Michael Feathers' book /Working Effectively with Legacy Code/.
I read the =
sample chapter on the net, it's very interesting and
practical. Must be the=
 next book to order...
 
> I'd suggest classes which are likely to be worke=
d on "soon". Those are,
> after all, the ones which you might otherwise bre=
ak, and for which
> unit tests will add most value.
> 
> It's tempting to s=
tart with "easy" ones, but you run the risk of writing
> tests for things t=
hat won't change and won't break, and you'd gain an
> unrealistic view of h=
ow easy it is(n't) to add tests post-hoc.

Yes, actually writing JUnit test=
s is just another development
task/cycle you must put efforts in to explore=
 bugs at unit-level,
isn't it. Perhaps the TDD methodology mixes these two =
development
cycles nattily...

It would be interesting to see a statistics =
how many bugs an
OO-project has at unit-level and how many at integration-l=
evel (during
cooperation of objects).

Thanks Chris,
 csaba
